reviewText:
ZMR has a great collection of game modes and memorable maps from other series of games. You can play a round of Demolition on a map similar to de_dust from Counter-Strike one round and then switch to a spinoff of Call of Duty's Nazi Zombies survival mode. ZMR operates like Gears of War mechanically but offers a plethora of game modes in both PvP and PvE that mix things up enough to keep interest.

There is a weapon rental system similar to a lot of Korean Shooter MMOs, but permanent versions of guns are readily available and obtainable without spending money (granted some take a lot more grinding than others)

Rewards from PvE are received through a system similar to Payday 2 while PvP rewards are a chest system like CS:GO has. Doing both will earn in game currency and chances at gear through completing quests, which could include objects like Kill 5 enemies with a shotgun" or "Complete X PvE scenario" and other similar quests.

My biggest concern stepping into a free shooter is whether I have to pay money or grind for hours to stand a chance against established
date:
and this isn't the case. Starting guns and guns earned through quests are extremely capable and I've never been killed because someone else had a bigger gun than me.


Overall
hoursPlayed: above average shooter that is definitely worth a try (it's free

reviewText:
A fun game if you're looking for team work, light customization, and killin zombies!...and monsters...and robots....DINOSAURS TOO. The game is full of video game references. For example a costume of Leona and Ralf from the King of Fighters (NeoGeo). A little Contra (NES), and Call of Duty Zombies. There's probably more, and it makes the game a bit more interesting and fun to play...until the repitition gets boring

Right off the bat you'll notice the graphics looks a bit dated. Textures aren't photo realistic, and the models are low poly by modern gaming standards. But if that spoils a game for you, you might as well jump ship now.

Controls could probably use some tweaking..and you cant crouch even though theres a button setting for it. Running, rolling, and taking cover is all one button, and while this makes it easy to play, it also makes it frusturating when youre trying to take cover, and instead your character rolls. There seems to be no way to jump either...which would make the game a bit more fun if you can get onto different platforms....or jump over obstacles etc.

My biggest gripe is that the guns are all pretty much the same, in terms of damage output, and tweaks. If anything, there are slight differences, but not much to favor one gun over the other based on performance. Best thing to do is to get something that you think looks cool. And speaking of cool, it seems that thats what they are going for when it comes to the guns. Blue camo paint? Yellow? wtf? Where's my Caution Tape camo then? These are the guns that are supposed perform best!

There's also weapon pickups, if you run out of ammo, and there arent any crates or anything...Cool! But then when you realise you cant even buy most of them, its not so cool.  And then there's the heavy weapons that you can only pickup on the battlefield, which is a real treat if you want a BFG with a ton of bullets. These guns can overheat and stop firing, which balances things out...but why cant LMG's overheat then? As it is, the only weapon you REALLY want to get the most kills is an LMG.

Despite these shortcomings, I still play the game. It's a nice refreshment if you're bored of Battlefield or COD....Or if you're a retro gamer looking for a game full of cameo♥♥♥♥♥♥ences.

reviewText: ZMR is F2P Gears of War meets The Secret World. its not a utterly terrible game as other reviews led me to believe. But it does have a unavoidable renting system to keep you returning on a regular basis but the ingame quest system allows you to contenually get items and feel progression as you play even for a short time, other then renting, the game is a third person (over the shoulder) shooter with general custonization and gear/vanity items to collect as well as weapons of course, also includes some fun PvE Coop with multiple gamemodes ranging from CoD Zombies to Killing Floor type matches on intresting and long/huge iconic Gears and CoD levels/missions (remade in ZMR style) against crazy bosses/enemies pulled from Fantasy, Mythology and Sci Fi. The PvP is ok,with lots of gamemodes like normal human v human (on your custom char) and L4D  style pvp, with man vs moster and many more (PvP and PvE) modes.

reviewText:
Imagine a third person shooter that combines aspects from CoD:Zombies and Gears of War. Combine it with competitive PvP/PvE action, largely detailed maps and objectives, with a lot to choose from, and you have a short synopse of ZMR.

I've grown bored when it comes to shooters these days. They just don't appeal to me as much as they used to. ZMR, however, has added a bit more to the table. Much like other shooters though, there's a currency system that can be used to purchase mods for weapons, outfits that you can accessorize your character with to make him/her stand out from the rest, and a few other minor things that slowly add up that make ZMR that much better.

Now I will admit, just like any other shooter, it can get a bit repetative. So make sure to switch things up a bit and try out different maps and modes.

I say, that if  you're unsure about wanting to invest the time to see if it's a good game, just try it out for maybe 30 minutes to an hour and see how you like it. I mean after all, it is free to play. What do you have to lose?

reviewText: From what I've seen while I played? It's a PC Gears multiplayer clone, with a faster pace. Which isnt a bad thing. As seen during the lag issue accompanying the steam launch, the developers are quite transparent and have so far been rather active on the forums, which is always a plus.\nIt does fall prey to the usual foul-ups that f2p games have, where there is an absurd grind for free players to purchase permanent weapons. This is allieviated by a free one every 10 character levels, and the lottery system, which rolls the dice and can give you a perm weapon, although that is somewhat rare.\nThe 'Revive-Token' system would be fine if it didn't kick you in coop matches 105 seconds after death if you don't use your limited amount of revive tokens. As it is, I would wait until it's got like 5 seconds until kick, and then use one.

reviewText:
I'll be honest at first the reviews had me concerned about even downloading ZMR, but I'm glad I went for it anyway because I was pleasantly surprised by what I found. Granted I did have very low expectations going in, the last game I played like this was God Mode and anyone who bought that knows how it turned out.

I don't see how people say its P2W, regular guns can be either rented or permanently unlocked with either EMP or Gold you earn in game. Special items like ZK and Assault guns do have added benefits like larger magazine sizes, which you could get mods for you regular guns anyhow, but any significant damage buffs with those weapons are restricted to certain PVE modes.

A decent selection of the clothing can also be unlocked with Gold, the better looking stuff will cost you money through EMP though these are Outfits" so they're complete sets that it doesnt seem you can mix and match. However that does bring me to an issue I have with the game.

The way EMP is priced in comparison to the Store. The minimum purchase you can make for EMP is $10 USD
recommended: this usually wouldn't be a problem except for the way some items are priced. Take one of those Premium skins for example
hoursPlayed: they cost 1195 EMP
voteText: so if you wanted a Premium skin you'll be expected to pay out $20 with points left over. I absolutely hate when games do this
helpfulPercent: if you can't make it a flat price for a skin at least add a $5 option in the game so players won't be left with a large amount of point's left over especially if there's nothing they want but one skin.\n\nThe game uses Revive Tokens in PVE which originally I didn't like the idea of but the more I played
votesHelpful: the more I became use to it and at the rate they're given out in this game you honestly won't have to worry about having to pay out for them.\n\nI'll admit I haven't played much of the PVP but there are quite a few modes
votesTotal: the three I played are two standard modes
votesFunny: Team Deathmatch and a Sabatage (plant the bomb) mode. The third mode I played is called Mercs vs Monsters

column16: as the game goes on and you get kills you earn points which yo ucan use to spawn as more powerful characters with different abilities. You play one round as the Mercs and one round as the Zombies
column17: whichever has the highest at the end of the game or reaches the score cap wins.\n\nThe maps could be better designed but for a game that involves running around and shooting everything

reviewText:
While no game is perfect, especially in the universe of free to play games, ZMR is pretty entertaining and dosnt seem to beat you as heavily over the head with pay walls as some other F2P shooters. Your initially presented with a set of permanent newbie stuff that never goes away, but before you can really use it much you do the tutorial and subsiquent tasks netting early temporary gear.

ZMR uses a combination of gambling (through 'bullet' tokens you earn playing or buy), Gear Rental and Limited revive tokens to allow you to play but also encourage you to spend money in some fashion. You get three freebie revives every match you play and then earn silver premium revives you can burn after that (iv played a day and a half and have like forty of those as they are the primary reward from gambling with bullet tokens)

You also can pick up weapons from enemies or spend score points you earn ina  match to pick up specially spawned weapons (depending on the map type) in a very CoD zombie fashion which means you dont really NEED a special weapon to just pick something up and start wooping ♥♥♥ (TommyGun how I love thee). The graphics are nothing special, not ugly but nothing 'next gen', this also means it runs fairly well on low end machines, perfect for you poor slobs in college that cant afford real video games eh? Most of the enemies, bosses and maps are very entertaining, though dinosaurs get annoying fast.

Gameplay wise its something like the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ child of Gears of War horde mode, Mass Effect 3 multiplayer and call of duty zombie ops with the comic humor from Loadout, all in all I would recommend this to anyone that enjoys any of those.

EDIT: Few days later still enjoying the game and remarkably, enjoying some of the pvp as well: the monster vs mercs is a riot (especially the exploding dog). The gambling system is still, well gambling and I hate gambling: so far with only the silver/gold bullets iv only turned up INSANE amounts of revive tokens(100+) and a handful of rental mods.  Also looks like they use a Loot Case somewhat like Star Trek's boxes that you need to buy keys from the cash shop to open, so gambling with real money...not a big fan of that idea got burned by star trek that way. They do feed you a steady supply of rental weapons and as you level, perma ones  (AR at lvl1, SMG at lvl10, shotgun at lvl20, ect) but the fancy paint job weapons have extra damage in certain map types while the permanent lvl guys dont have this boost.

reviewText:
The game is ok, but it was just released, so developers will most likely make adjustments in the future.  The major problem right now seems to be lag/ping issues in every game. I really like the concept of the game though, the graphics and the coop parts. It feels like it's another Combat Arms or A.V.A.

*Edit* After playing it a while now, the lag is fixed, and I am loving the PvP and PvE modes, offering a wide variety of gameplay.  The graphics are a bit better than games like Combat Arms, and the movement of the character, and being able to take cover from gunfire is very nice.

I really like the reward system with the silver/gold bullets, kind of like a scratch ticket and see what you win. And you recieve some after most rounds, and is very useful to gain revives for your monster game modes.  I also like how you can get many nice items through completing daily missions and such. The market/store system is good, but I am hoping as the game updates more, they will add more gear/weapons for regular currency users, instead of EMP points or cash currency.

reviewText:
Game is extremely fun and well put together. I'm a huge fan of co-op shooters, and this game makes it worth the download. Sure the lag comes in in the afternoon times, but I've looked on the reddit and the steam news that they are working on fixing it. When the lag gets fixed this game will have my attention for  quite sometime. Sure it uses the average free to play shooter item rentals.....But how do you expect them to make money? You can buy permanent versions of all weapons with in game gold if you play long enough and do all the missions.

With new updates very often, new modes, campaigns, weapons, and outfits, I highly reccomend ZMR to anyone who likes Gears of War, Resident Evil, or just flat down shooting zombies.

Download this now, maybe play a little later at night for now when not many people are on, so you don't lag. This should be fixed in the next day or two according to the ZMR reddit.

reviewText:
In the spirit of the creatures that ZMR loves to espouse, let's say Dr. Frankenstein (pronounced fronk-un-steen) made a monster. That monster was made up of a mishmash of parts from different corpses. Unfortunately, the parts were taken from different low-level corporate managers. That monster's name was ZMR, and boy was it utterly bland and woefully uninteresting.

Zombies Monsters Robots is built with systems from other games, and none of the polish or the flavor of any of them. Take a dash of Gears of War here, throw in a little Resident Evil Mercenaries, add a little Call of Duty Zombies, throw on a coat of dated visuals, and there you have ZMR.

The enemies are variations of three archetypes; a fast melee, a ranged, and a buffed health. Whether zombies, monsters, or robots, they're all the same under different skins. PVP is a race to see which team can spawn camp before the other.

A promising premise, but a disappointing result.

reviewText:
What could have been an absolutely amazing game is marred by clunky controls, laughably bad AI, terrible netcode, and just generally repetitive and mundane gameplay. The only time I began to had any fun was PvP closely coordinated with a few friends over TeamSpeak. Did I mention horrible F2P gear rental mechnic? Ugh.

This game is beautiful, the graphics are crisp and beautiful, the character design intriguing. However, I found that the best solution in PvE mode is to just gung-ho it and revive as necessary. Every few days you'll make a few revive tokens by completing missions or getting loot packages. The AI is so laughably braindead and non-threatening that boss battles usually consist of the entire team emptying round after round into boss in a straight line till it drops. The exciting premise of fighting hordes of zombies, monsters and/or robots is completely lost when in a single mission you run the same small map back and forth to either way for an objective, or do a pickup and drop mission whie mobs run straight at you. After the fifth time of going back to the same area for a nearly identical objective I gave up on the dinosaur themed map.

The bane of F2P, it certainly didn't cost me anything, but if this had been a polished, pay experience I think would have been happy.

reviewText:
Enjoyable PVE.

PvP wise there are definitely better PvP shooters out there, however they do have a fun MvM mode where you're basically playing the NPCs you fight in PvE.

You can definitely tell which one is preferred by how many people are in each lobby, in the PvP one, very few, in the PvE one, quite a bit.

It has a lot of potential, I'd recommend this game right now, but, it's got a bit to go until it's truly better than some similar titles like Mass Effect 3 Multiplayer, which is light years better than this game.

Still, pretty fun, and not Pay 2 Win.

reviewText: I recommend this game. It is in between pay 2 win and grind 2 win. You can win every item in the store by playing the missions. A lot of games like this don't offer that. It is fair in a lot of ways. The only problem I really find annoying is when you run out of revives during a game. I started up a boss rush and got to the very last boss.. I ran out of revive tokens and I couldn't join the game. Eventually I got kicked. So all that hard work was for nothing... I think the free revive tokens you get should be increased per difficulty. At least increased to 5 on expert mode. Another tedious thing is when you constantly have to see the same cut scenes everytime you play a map on PvE. Maybe it would be wise to limit the cut scenes to only boss entrances and major details. Instead add quest markers. Add quest markers for when you have to activate a switch or something beause it gets really annoying... Thats one of the MAJOR things that turn me off from playing. I would play a lot more than I already do if it wasn't for all the cut scenes.. Just the thought of grinding another map with the thought in the back of my mind I really want to grind this map again but I really dont want to deal with all the cut scenes".. Like really. Its super annoying. This game is good! The boss fights are awesome and tough! but those damn cut scenes kill it hard."

reviewText:
I have no idea what in the hell I should say about this game, but I'll give it a try.

ZMR is a pretty half-decent free to play game. It plays alright, the shooting is responsive, but movement is a little sloppy. Graphics are fine, and enemy variety is actually pretty good.

The progression system actually feels rather quick for a free to play game. So the issue is really with enemies being rather damaging and the levels being fairly cheap in finding ways to get you killed so you have to use your daily alottment of revive tokens.

I mean, seriously, having a level where you have to pretty much time your movements perfectly in order to dodge a train and live is one of the most ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t things I can think of.

Overall, it's fun to play with a friend or two for a little while, but beyond that it gets a little stale.

I'm recommending it on the basis that it's free to play and easy to shoot the ♥♥♥♥ in for a couple hours.

reviewText:
Hello, boys and girls! Want to play a game where you struggle against 150+ ping Brazalians? How about a game where experianced players jump on alt accounts, just so they can stick it to the noobs in the lower level PvP rooms? You're in luck! ZMR is the game for you.

Experiance all of the teleporting, bullet sponging madness that you can possibly imagine! Laugh with joy as you shoot an opponent in the head several times, but die to a body shot!

The fun doesn't stop there: experiance true frustration, as you get instant killed by people hiding behind a corner with a gun they bought, and is superior to your own!

Enjoy the constant onslaught of spanish in the chatbox, all the while being spawn camped by a team of highly experianced players in a lobby not meant for them.

Waste countless hours of your life grinding to unlock cosmetic items for your character, and twice as much to buy new weapons and mods!

Revel in the glory of not being able to shoot over, or around, cover for no reason!

Seriously, boys and girls, stay away from the PvP unless you're very skilled at TPS. The PvE is actually a fairly good time, with various game modes and maps.

reviewText:
Personally, I disliked it. The gameplay is okay when you come around to your first mission and the tutorial, but afterwards it's not really worth it. Just like most free-to-play games, it is heavily oriented around purchasing an in-game currency that is only available via purchase anyway. There's not that many guns, not that many outfits, etc.
It has great looks though but otherwise there's not enough to it, and the lag is absolutely horrid, and in this case it's just connection. Otherwise it works great.

I was hearing that this game is more around new release though, so I will give it credit to beginning, but otherwise it's not very preferred.
You'd be better off playing Gears Of War really.

My official review at ♥♥♥♥♥♥mes
(~25 hours clocked on non-steam client)

--
Two years ago, En Masse pitched its first game, TERA, to the public promoting a revolutionary" MMORPG combat system that has not been seen prior. Through personal experience I would have to agree that it lived up to its claims and is now free to play with a stable community. With this in mind
date: I happily gave ZMR a go. Besides
recommended: who isn't a fan of zombies monsters and
hoursPlayed: or robots
voteText: anyway?\n\nTo create an abundantly unique persona
helpfulPercent: carefully select one of seven faces
votesHelpful: your skin color
votesTotal: a painfully common hairstyle
votesFunny: and one of five virtually similar voices. After which
commentsCount: you may proceed to enter the game and
column16: against your will
column17: accept a five to ten minute tutorial explaining the basics of weapon swapping
column18: movement mechanics
column19: target practice and… You guessed it
column20: ZOMBIES! All narrated by your typical cocky military sergeant who respectfully prefers to be identified as
column21: “The Boss”.\n\nIn ZMR
column22: you are a soldier for a corporation primarily involved with running missions and making monies. If you don’t read much on their website
column23: you may not realize that you are actually battling dimensional forces that all seem to want Earth for some unexplained reason. Beyond this
column24: there is no plot whatsoever
column25: most likely to save you the headache of another redundant apocalypse theory. It’s best to keep in mind that this game is very arcade.\n\nBeing the seasoned PvP gamer that I am
column26: I immediately jumped into PvP where I got to rock it out with a few other lowbies. I loved juking around corners and the ability to shoot my gun from cover without actually aiming down sights. This is not common in games that utilize these types of movement mechanics and allows you the element of suppressive fire as your team mates attempt to flank and gank. I also enjoyed the reload feature which allows you to speed up (or fail to) reload times. But be careful of weapon jamming!\n\nThere is no matchmaker in ZMR. Instead
column27: players host lobbies and lobby control is passed in succession as players come and go. Most often
column28: a game lobby will last about three to five games. This can get a little irritating
column29: but at the same time you may find yourself switching between game modes quite often as the gameplay in each gets to be a little redundant. One positive (and sometimes negative)
column31:
is that you can invite entire lobbies to your game. So be ready for the mass invitation spam.

Free for all / Deathmatch / Team Death match / Elimination
The primary objective of each of these modes is to eliminate the opposing team. In deathmatch
column34: there is a respawn function with a time limit and or a number of kills to reach before the game ends. In elimination
column35: there is a set of rounds and one life per round. Friendly fire and weapon restrictions are optional to the host
column36:
and you may also choose to have set teams or balanced teams.

Demolition / King of the hill
Demolition features your typical plant/defuse scenario where one team plants a bomb and the other attempts to defuse it within the time limit. King of the hill
column38: is point control. Don’t expect to find many of these games on the list.\n\nDepending on your experience in shooters
column39: you may realize that Call of Duty made a baby with Gears of War. In the majority of the modes
column40: the movement mechanics and camera functions of ZMR are nearly a carbon copy of GoW while in PvP modes
column41: you remain as fragile as glass. All in all
column42: the arsenal of modern day weapons to select from is pretty well balanced considering the practice needed to master each of them. Plus
column43: you will find yourself adopting numerous tactics to stay alive. If you happen to be up against an experienced player during your first few hours
column44:
prepare for the rage.

Mercs vs. Monsters (MvM)
If you're playing PvP but still want to get your zombie on

reviewText:
This game is what happens when you monetize every last aspect of a game. Somewhere deep within the microtransactions is a wave survival game where you need to traverse a map, avoid deadly traps and defeat a final boss to win. So how much is monetized? Let me tell ya:

* Want one of those guns that are obviously a direct upgrade from stock? Guess what, you pay to RENT them.
* Want to own that gun forever? Well, you'll have to cough up some real-world money for that!
* Cosmetics? You'd better believe you'd have to pay to run around in anything other than a dirty undershirt.
* Died in game and want to respawn? That costs a respawn token which, surprise, costs money!

Most annoyingly, even if you delete local content, this game remains in your library, something which no other free game in my experience does. You have to use the Steam Help site in order to remove it from your account.

reviewText: The Good, The Bad & the Ugly\nZMR does have a lot or good things, like a fresh new spin on shooters as well as having a lot of things happening. But thats where the problems start. You can do a few quest like the Daily quest and get some cool gear, But the gear; weapons, clothes or booster will only last 2-30 days 30 days being the MOST, but a 2 day expiring item is the MOST COMMON. Oh it get worse, on the Minesweeper map in co-op my teammates and me had the faced great foe like none other...a minecart. NO REALLY!! we had to duck and dodge a minecart while get hit by an range zombie that when u took damage your HUD got blurry and usually the minecart got you. Also ZMR trieds to be original but uses the Gears of War formula, which isn't useful against zombie...Futher more if u get knock down you have to spam the SPACE bar to slow down the bleeding you can move but that causes you to bleed out more! But on the upside ZMR was serious about the enemy fractions, but i don't understand why the dinosaur have the same behavior to the zombies yet the dinos have turrets and machine guns on their bodys? Oh and it gets down right ugly to get a permanent weapon u need to be a millionare (not a joke) i have no problem grinder but 100,000 gold just for a sidearm?! and it the cheap version that only last a few day?!? WAT? Also ZMR breaks videogame logic, please hear me out i played many games ranging from xbox, playstation, to nintendo. So tell me how u would feel if you killed a giant cockroach that sparys acid, can 1 shot players with an melee and after your team kills it no boss loot? Did you hear me? i kill at least 4-5 bosses and no boss loot of any kind. I turned in to Michael from RoosterTeeth when he does a Rage Quit video but the RAGE was 100% REAL. This was 100% USDA RAGE, i'm not a bias gamer i played alot of games BUT!! ZMR might be the defintion of PAY-To-WIN. *IF YOU DON'T BELIEVE ME TRY IT*

reviewText: So, as first impressions go, this game gets about a negative five out of ten for me. First, it opens up in a stupid windowed mode that isn't fullscreen. Second, it starts off with ridiculously loud music (so loud it completely drowns out the voices you're trying to select from at the character creator) and you can't access any settings until you've created your character and loaded into the tutorial. Extremely annoying, but ok, I can deal with that. Next, apparently humans can't jump. (A big WTF, but still, not a total deal-breaker.) But the thing that completely killed it for me was the keybinds for shooting and weapon scope. LMB = shoot, pretty standard. RMB = hold to aim, also pretty standard. Mouse wheel = activate scope and adjust zoom, which you can only do while holding down the aim button. So to use a scope you need 3 fingers where there's only room for two on virtually every mouse ever made. And the best part? You can't change these keybinds. Deleting this garbage was an easy choice.

reviewText:
People play this game and then wonder why they get their asses handed at them in other multiplayer games.

My biggest issue with this game is the next to none existent AI in the enemy units. The pretty much move towards you and shoot. All the excitement and stress comes from you trying to avoid getting overwhelmed. But if you stay calm and play well there is no sense of urgency or strategy.

It pains me when gamers enjoy games like there which are dumb unimaginative everyone runs in a straight line at you. Too be fair this formula can be well done. Take the same premise and for some reason Killing Floor succeeds with flying colors.

Perhaps it's just the gunplay that feels dull and the encounters. The reloading feel like an annoying mini game which I could do without. I admit it was a cool idea in gears of war, but I preferred it in Halo 1. If you hit the melee button just at the right moment when reloading your pistol if would reload slightly faster due to the different animation change, but at least it wouldn't Jam your whole gun and slow down the whole gun play just because you weren't paying enough attention to the little line on the screen syncing up instead of paying attention to the battlefield.

I always refer to FEAR 1's AI, just play that game and compare the AI of this game.

Yes the game looks good, it's sexy the controls are tight, the sound is decent. But personally I think it fails in the most important category. It's not all that fun.

I think the AI could be compared to Wolfenstein 3D, except Wolf3D actually has interesting maps with doors and mazes which keep the playing interested.

There are Many free to play games, and I'd recommend many others before I'd recommend this.

And the funny thing is the game is painted as fun with Zombies Monsters and Robots, but at the core it's pretty dull.

reviewText: ZMR is sort of a mixed bag of fun. While it's true that most weapons and cosmetics cost real world money, they can also be earned with in game gold. Prices for renting seem to be fair and cheap, and you can permanently purchase 90% of items in games with in game money alone. The few that are restricted to premimum cash are all cosmetic, with the only stat boosting items being gloves and boots, which merely increase XP and gold by 3-5%. Not a large difference over all.\n\nThe combat is your standard third person shooter fair, but it seems to be trying to make it fun at least. With a Sticky
date:
cover system akin to Gears of War, an active reload that is an exact copy of GoW's, and well designed weapons, it at least plays well. Most weapons are moddable, with things such as steel barrels for longer range, or bayonets for vastly increased melee damage. So far, all the mod slots have only had one option, meaning you don't have to pick and choose to make the perfect build. This can be annoying to some people, but I personally prefer upgrading a weapon to be a straight linear path.

As for the weapons themselves, they are mostly well designed and based around skill. Though there are some weapons that seem over powered (Damn you, Uzi blind fire) for the most part they all work in their respective niches. Further more, they are very skill based. If you have a steady hand and are patient enough, it's entirely possible to snipe across maps with the starter sidearm, though very difficult. Weapons can be reloaded while sprinting and rolling, preventing you from being locked into long animations with no way to counter.

The cover system has a few flaws. Most notably, if you vault a cover piece and continue to hold sprint, you will merely jog forward, which is sometimes the difference between life and death. Sometimes you will get stuck on wall polyogons, or ping wildly across the the wall, sometimes even through it... Which brings me to my main complaint. Any amount of ping above 50 will massively affect your gameplay. I regularly am forced to play with ping in the upper 200s, and it's damn near unplayable at times. Every person who kills me does so with flawless headshots through walls, while I can only score kills on ambushes or direct instant kill headshots.

Despite all the issues just mentioned however, the game at it's core remains fun. I've had a blast, sprinting with six others through an Egyptian pyramid while fleeing from mummies and dogs with bombs strapped to them, desperately mashing R to reload in time to unload on the horde just around the next corner. Sitting in the top of a tower with two friends, holding a choke point in the middle of a PVP match so our team can regroup and push forward up the middle of the train. Sprinting down a shortcut and ambushing the highest scoring enemy player just before he can execute my sniper buddy, then reviving him and laying a claymore trap that takes out three enemies at once. Desperately dancing through a horde of giants with battle axes, fleeing from Anubis himself while my teammates dump hundreds of pounds of lead into him, then turning and finishing him off with a last ditch headshot.

I started this game on a whim, half wondering just how bad it would be. And in truth, there's quite a bit of bad to be had here. But the sheer fun the game over shadows that. I've had more campy, cheesy, silly fun with this game than I've had in months. And the fact it's free just makes it better.

Now I may not have a lot of time with this, but I have played a game like it called S4 League or something like that, anyways.

I do not recommend this game due to the 'Give us your money to keep your weapons ^_^' The Devs seem to think is okay, which happens due to the people who actually pay money for said weapons. But everyone has already talked about the Pay To Suck Dev C**k aspect of this game.

Pro's: Nice little Desktop icon on your Desktop.

Con's: Ohh Lordy where do I begin, well, first off the game Tutorial is for if you have never played a Game in your life and treats you kind of like a five year old with Daddy's gun. The control's feel slow as well, making your evasion of gunfire hard and then pointless when all the Grenade Launcher carrying S.O.B.'S come out in the Co-op aspect. Zombies felt like a good idea til you realized it was a super Cheap version of that one made by COD's Dev's.
I didn't try Jurassic, I got kicked from the first Zombie attempt and The Second seemed even more worthless attempt as it was all a bunch of LMG's cause every other gun is damn near useless.

PVP is most likely something that you want to avoid, I didn't try it as PVP in these Game's tends to come down to who Paid more of their hard earned cash to get Shiny Sword Mk.69, that or Aim bots and Super Speed hack with Infinite Explosives to kill you without trying.

OH! I almost forgot the most Horrendous Idea that I have ever seen in a Co-op mode, if you die, rather than have a respawn timer and some points taken away, you get Auto-kicked in 120 Seconds if you do not have a token, which you can get from Silver bullets at the shooting range or Pay with Even MORE of your money! Co-op is more just Co-Flop, cause unless your like everyone else and have some Payed for weapon, your not going to be doing much more than being The Camera man, aka your watching but not doing.

Altogether, I suggest taking your Time, Money and Possibly Lovely as The Night Sky filled with Stars PC and Go to some other Online Third Person Shooter, or maybe just go play an MMO, or FPS, or something Two to Ten times better than this Turd.

reviewText:
What is ZMR?
ZMR is a fun diversion that needs some work and possibly a new game mechanic to make it great.  Its a third-person shooter in which players fight Zombies, Monsters, or Robots.  ZMR, get it?  Simular to Gears of War, with the ability to cling to cover, blind fire, and finishing moves for downed opponets, ZMR has different sized maps for PVE or PVP play.  As players defeat oponents and maps they are rated on how well they did and are rewarded with experience and items that level up their characters.

Having only played PVE, I find the CO-OP fun, but I feel the game gets unfair at times.   Some maps have  tough areas were players will die repeatedly because they didnt line up perfectly behind cover.  Heaven help you if there is only one item to use as cover in a room.  Now you have to watch as your allies get downed and you cant help them without dying yourself.  You can spend your respawn tokens to return only to die again and again.  Respawn tokens are plentiful but its a pain to go thru this over and over.  Also, some boss fights can be very cheap with instant kills abilities.  Sure you may see the attack comming but there may only be one safe spot on the map and your character is just too slow to get there. Or there is only that one cover item in the room.  This all matters because you are rated on how well you did on a map and that affects the experience you get.

The worst part of ZMR is the rent-a-item system.  Few of the best weapons, clothing items, and weapon mods are permanent.  After a purchase with gold earned in game the items will expire after a number of days.   I understand why developers would create such a system but this only turns players into junkies.  Here take this weapon, when it expires, come back to me for another hit. Maybe I am being a little dramatic but in other Free-to-Play games,  weapons and items dont have to be rented. They can be earned or bought and I have done both. Real cash can be used in ZMR but I have yet to spend any.

I like ZMR but the unfairness in the battles on some maps and the rent-a-item system are a big turn off.  I like a challenge but get frustrated with dying multiple times over bad gameplay designs or looking at all the cool stuff that will expire after I obtained it.   However, I really like what  this game offers and will try to stick with it.  I just hope the game developers can fix some of the issues before my patience wears off.

I give ZMR a hesitant Like, Thumbs UP,...you get the idea

reviewText:
Now I may not have a lot of time with this, but I have played a game like it called S4 League or something like that, anyways.

I do not recommend this game due to the 'Give us your money to keep your weapons ^_^' The Devs seem to think is okay, which happens due to the people who actually pay money for said weapons. But everyone has already talked about the Pay To Suck Dev C**k aspect of this game.

Pro's: Nice little Desktop icon on your Desktop.

Con's: Ohh Lordy where do I begin, well, first off the game Tutorial is for if you have never played a Game in your life and treats you kind of like a five year old with Daddy's gun. The control's feel slow as well, making your evasion of gunfire hard and then pointless when all the Grenade Launcher carrying S.O.B.'S come out in the Co-op aspect. Zombies felt like a good idea til you realized it was a super Cheap version of that one made by COD's Dev's.
I didn't try Jurassic, I got kicked from the first Zombie attempt and The Second seemed even more worthless attempt as it was all a bunch of LMG's cause every other gun is damn near useless.

PVP is most likely something that you want to avoid, I didn't try it as PVP in these Game's tends to come down to who Paid more of their hard earned cash to get Shiny Sword Mk.69, that or Aim bots and Super Speed hack with Infinite Explosives to kill you without trying.

OH! I almost forgot the most Horrendous Idea that I have ever seen in a Co-op mode, if you die, rather than have a respawn timer and some points taken away, you get Auto-kicked in 120 Seconds if you do not have a token, which you can get from Silver bullets at the shooting range or Pay with Even MORE of your money! Co-op is more just Co-Flop, cause unless your like everyone else and have some Payed for weapon, your not going to be doing much more than being The Camera man, aka your watching but not doing.

Altogether, I suggest taking your Time, Money and Possibly Lovely as The Night Sky filled with Stars PC and Go to some other Online Third Person Shooter, or maybe just go play an MMO, or FPS, or something Two to Ten times better than this Turd.

reviewText: ZMR is sort of a mixed bag of fun. While it's true that most weapons and cosmetics cost real world money, they can also be earned with in game gold. Prices for renting seem to be fair and cheap, and you can permanently purchase 90% of items in games with in game money alone. The few that are restricted to premimum cash are all cosmetic, with the only stat boosting items being gloves and boots, which merely increase XP and gold by 3-5%. Not a large difference over all.\n\nThe combat is your standard third person shooter fair, but it seems to be trying to make it fun at least. With a Sticky
date:
cover system akin to Gears of War, an active reload that is an exact copy of GoW's, and well designed weapons, it at least plays well. Most weapons are moddable, with things such as steel barrels for longer range, or bayonets for vastly increased melee damage. So far, all the mod slots have only had one option, meaning you don't have to pick and choose to make the perfect build. This can be annoying to some people, but I personally prefer upgrading a weapon to be a straight linear path.

As for the weapons themselves, they are mostly well designed and based around skill. Though there are some weapons that seem over powered (Damn you, Uzi blind fire) for the most part they all work in their respective niches. Further more, they are very skill based. If you have a steady hand and are patient enough, it's entirely possible to snipe across maps with the starter sidearm, though very difficult. Weapons can be reloaded while sprinting and rolling, preventing you from being locked into long animations with no way to counter.

The cover system has a few flaws. Most notably, if you vault a cover piece and continue to hold sprint, you will merely jog forward, which is sometimes the difference between life and death. Sometimes you will get stuck on wall polyogons, or ping wildly across the the wall, sometimes even through it... Which brings me to my main complaint. Any amount of ping above 50 will massively affect your gameplay. I regularly am forced to play with ping in the upper 200s, and it's damn near unplayable at times. Every person who kills me does so with flawless headshots through walls, while I can only score kills on ambushes or direct instant kill headshots.

Despite all the issues just mentioned however, the game at it's core remains fun. I've had a blast, sprinting with six others through an Egyptian pyramid while fleeing from mummies and dogs with bombs strapped to them, desperately mashing R to reload in time to unload on the horde just around the next corner. Sitting in the top of a tower with two friends, holding a choke point in the middle of a PVP match so our team can regroup and push forward up the middle of the train. Sprinting down a shortcut and ambushing the highest scoring enemy player just before he can execute my sniper buddy, then reviving him and laying a claymore trap that takes out three enemies at once. Desperately dancing through a horde of giants with battle axes, fleeing from Anubis himself while my teammates dump hundreds of pounds of lead into him, then turning and finishing him off with a last ditch headshot.

I started this game on a whim, half wondering just how bad it would be. And in truth, there's quite a bit of bad to be had here. But the sheer fun the game over shadows that. I've had more campy, cheesy, silly fun with this game than I've had in months. And the fact it's free just makes it better.

reviewText:
I played this game for about an hour before getting severly bored. It's basically a GunZ 2 sequel/ripoff...

It's the same graphics, the same basic enemy and player types. Of course there are absolutely NO usefull explanations as to how the more complex game features work, and no explanations as to where you can use each player type (specifficaly Mechs). I played 3.5 hours and by the end I still had no idea where I could play as a Mech. And not a single person replied to my questions in the chat.

The missions are boring. And almost impossible on your own. The voice acting" is ridiculous. There is no depth to any of the characters (just boobs
date: and those can only keep you interested so long...). It's basically just another... I'm so bored after playing this game I don't have no power to think of an ending to that sentence...\nAnd the game itself is pretty unstable. It crashed twice on the first launch
recommended:
and I think it even crashed my LAN card at one point. I'm not even sure how that's possible (first time it EVER happened to me).

Not to mention the whole Pay 2 Win system... So in PvP you go against these "gamers" that have some insane gear and they just F**K you up the a*s (pardon my French) the entire match.

In conclusion

reviewText: I should enjoy it, as this is a game that feels like it was made just for me, and yet it doesn't fill me with the same manic glee as such shooters as Cod: Zombies or GunZ: The Duel.\n\nHere is a game that has a lot of cool stuff going for it: ancient temples filled with zombies, Big Trouble in Little China callbacks with the Chinese temples and undead generals, orbital space lasers, Mayan ziggurats, dinosaurs, and some multiverse-spanning enemy called The Dominion". All of this lore that the creators put behind it
date: even though it's all stuff that's been done before
recommended: surprisingly makes the game feel unique.\n\nHowever
hoursPlayed: the gameplay itself is rather bland. There's no happy medium for the game in terms of challenge: levels are either too hard with players dropping every ten seconds and having to spend another Rev Token (which are easily obtained
voteText: thankfully)
helpfulPercent: or the levels are too easy with players scrambling all over the map to try to find something to kill before someone else gets to it. The scenarios don't appeared to be scaled to the number of players
votesHelpful: either
votesTotal: so the rofl-stomping of enemies by players gets reversed when one plays alone. The devs should either put a smaller player cap on some of these missions or scale the number and toughness of enemies to the number of players
votesFunny: because once you have 8 people on a single server with only 8 enemies at a time
commentsCount: it gets real boring real fast.\n\nKnow that I'm only talking about the PvE bits. I didn't try the PvP due to the wonky game controls and the inconsistent framerate. It's free
column16: and there's no pay-to-win as far as the PvE goes
column17: so check it out. You may very well like it. It feels like the creators were just as upset about the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ization of GunZ: The Duel by the makers of GunZ 2 as I was
column18: and so they made their own weird
column19: out-of-its-mind anime-esque 3rd-person-shooter shooter with dungeon missions. I may go back to it after they fine-tune it some more
column20: as this is one game that certainly isn't lacking in variety of content."

reviewText:
I only played for a few hours and I'm already bored to tears at this repetitive grindfest and a sense of dreadful impending boredom comes over me when I think of putting in a few more hours. It has a few shining, fun moments but they are heavily buried beneath bad game design and uninspired mechanics that most gamers should already be familiar with.

Besides that, there are the small but very irritating details that contributes to my negative outlook: there are intrusive cutscenes that show up when you or your teammates reach the end of a room (i.e. every other minute); the graphics of this game in an aesthetic sense is jarring and has absolutely now flow (imagine cardboard cut outs fighting other cardboard cuts, because that’s EXACTLY how it feels); This game should change its name to Zombies, Monsters, OR Robots because each stage/mode is separated as such, I expected a huge epic fight down in a large map where you hold your own (or with a team) against a variety of fearsome beasties and other terrifying monstrosities but all you get is “go into this room and slowly reach the end of it on this pre-adjusted conveyer belt/gondola/platform while fighting the increasingly difficult albeit same wave of cardboard enemies.”

I’m sorry but this game simply does not hold my interest and it doesn’t do anything new that I haven’t already played in other video games. The only thing this game has going for itself is that it has a nice extensive tutorial, it’s FREE 2 play, and (as a result of the previous) you can easily get a bunch of your close gaming buddies and have some fun together. But otherwise you’re probably not going to stick around for very long. The only people I can see still playing this though are those who put money into this, find these types of modes appealing (go fight a wave in one room and the same in the next room, fight several waves in the same room, and PVP), or people who like the random loot drop nature of F2P games. Apparently you can level up at a reasonably quick pace, as opposed to the extremely slow crawl of level progression found in most F2P’s, so it has that going for it but again I didn’t play long enough to get past level 3 because it wasn’t enough to hold my interest.

Even though I wouldn’t want to touch this with a digital ten and half foot gun, I still highly recommend that you at least give it a try and find out for yourself if you’re one of the few who might get a kick out of this game, you never know.

uhh...yea this game has enemies, maps, ideas, and game modes ripped straight from other games... cod zombie game mode where you survive a couple waves of zombies that dont get stronger. they break open steel bar windows in 2 seconds and tells you to repair them...just so they can get destroyed immidiatly.

It has the same exact controls as gears of war, theres even an execution mechanic where you finish off downed enemies, its just you swiping at them with a kitchen knife, there is no blood or sound effect. There are even locust clones...

I stood still in front of an enemy spawn for about 1 1/2 minutes eating their bullets, I was at half HP... 10/10
Its fun if you feel like remembering better games :D

reviewText:
I only played for a few hours and I'm already bored to tears at this repetitive grindfest and a sense of dreadful impending boredom comes over me when I think of putting in a few more hours. It has a few shining, fun moments but they are heavily buried beneath bad game design and uninspired mechanics that most gamers should already be familiar with.

Besides that, there are the small but very irritating details that contributes to my negative outlook: there are intrusive cutscenes that show up when you or your teammates reach the end of a room (i.e. every other minute); the graphics of this game in an aesthetic sense is jarring and has absolutely now flow (imagine cardboard cut outs fighting other cardboard cuts, because that’s EXACTLY how it feels); This game should change its name to Zombies, Monsters, OR Robots because each stage/mode is separated as such, I expected a huge epic fight down in a large map where you hold your own (or with a team) against a variety of fearsome beasties and other terrifying monstrosities but all you get is “go into this room and slowly reach the end of it on this pre-adjusted conveyer belt/gondola/platform while fighting the increasingly difficult albeit same wave of cardboard enemies.”

I’m sorry but this game simply does not hold my interest and it doesn’t do anything new that I haven’t already played in other video games. The only thing this game has going for itself is that it has a nice extensive tutorial, it’s FREE 2 play, and (as a result of the previous) you can easily get a bunch of your close gaming buddies and have some fun together. But otherwise you’re probably not going to stick around for very long. The only people I can see still playing this though are those who put money into this, find these types of modes appealing (go fight a wave in one room and the same in the next room, fight several waves in the same room, and PVP), or people who like the random loot drop nature of F2P games. Apparently you can level up at a reasonably quick pace, as opposed to the extremely slow crawl of level progression found in most F2P’s, so it has that going for it but again I didn’t play long enough to get past level 3 because it wasn’t enough to hold my interest.

Even though I wouldn’t want to touch this with a digital ten and half foot gun, I still highly recommend that you at least give it a try and find out for yourself if you’re one of the few who might get a kick out of this game, you never know.

blahblahblahblah~

reviewText:
So one night, Resident Evil 5, COD, Gears of war, and Left4Dead got really...Really... really drunk, and this is what resulted. In the aftermath, Turok got there and said I will have some of whatever you guys are having and the party started all over again. In the end the hotel room was trashed as where all of the party goers and no one really remembered what happened that night.

Who should play this game: People who like spraying down tons of Zombies and other mobs with a ton of bullets while playing with a bunch of their friends on scripted missions with over the top Boss fights or people who like some gears style PVP with even more people in game.

Some of the other reviews said you don't start the game with permanent weapons, but you do curently get two starter weapons: an assault rifle and a handgun that are permanent. While their are better guns in the game, the starter weapons are more than enough to do the job and you earn in game money to rent anything else you want and that is if you don't unlock anything free from the shooting gallery. I have already earned the best hand gun in the game from the gallery.

This game has a lot to offer and good servers too. I see no reason not to give it a try and decide for yourself being that it is free and you get a Saw machine gun free for 30 days, so why not...

|Pros|

Pve: It has a good well thought out pve game settting.

Graphics: high

Store: Is good so far in my view nothing that goes above and beond.

Gear: pretty straight forward you have pve and normal stock gear.

Missions: good thing most games however do this now.

|Cons|

Controls: The game is pretty buggy with its control functions. Also some controls are not able to be changed without having a macro mouse that has more buttons on it.

Balances: Unfortantly some of this game still isn't balanced and I fell these issues will never be changed. Shotgun for one shouldn't be able to do a roll and be able to one hit someone with only few of the shots actually hitting.

Lag: I don't undstand why this game has so much lag. This isn't FPS lag I stay at a constaint 60 fps with this computer I shouldn't have this issue at all.

Repetitive: You do the same thing over and over again.

reviewText:
Pro: Free
Con: Everything else

Poorly executed Gears of War clone. Can't complain much considering it's free to play, but in my opinion it's not worth the space on my hard drive. They're main selling point was coming off as a wacky save the world shooter, but it is very poorly executed. Gameplay is easy and repetitive. Obnoxiously repetitive. You're continuously moving in a clear straight line with enemies generally coming from one direction, and levels can be completed by simply spamming fire down the players line of sight. Also, out of bounds areas appear as large empty rooms that a player would assume is full of some kind of loot, but inches away a wall appears informing you you can't pass. Reloading is poor on machine guns. Rather than having the bar longer and a smaller window for the quick reload bonus, they simply slow the moving bar, making the reload bonus a near guarantee on LMG's. Running while moving left or right is a nightmare. There are more flaws, but I'm tired and have somewhere to be.

3/10 SonniPoints Not worth downloading.

Gameplay is a bit clunky and not teriably fluid.  Sprinting is a bit jerky, and you start huffing and puffing after like, 10 feet.

I played it because of the mechs, and they are not in any way special.  movement is awkward, at best.  You are either walking along at a slow speed, or jerking around with the boost.  Also, feels like the armor is made of balsa wood.

There are already a ton of (meh) fremium shooters out there, this one is exatly average.

reviewText: I used to love this game....until the last couple days I was playing.  I was willing to put up with the cheaters and the high pings from players outside NA.  I made a couple comments today about the increase in hacking that I have observed in the past little while and I was called numerous names over megaphone and whispered to by people who thought they were the games elite.  They said I was ruining the game by making comments like that.  I never hackusate people specifically but I have been playing video games, and this game, long enough to know what you can and cant do...or whats possible and what is just luck and what is simply botting or whatever.  This game is no longer worth it.  Its free to play, and even void of a lot of pay to winness I've seen in other games.  I have even been tempted to pay real money to buy outfits and other things in the cash shop.  They say they are doing what they can about the hacking....but there is no anti-cheat system or any way of reporting cheaters.  I will still play this game from time to time, but I will never spend money on it or really ever put much time into it.  Spare yourself some anger and frustration....play something else.

reviewText: As with APB Reloaded the guns seem to be by and large time based weapons, i.e. you can only use it for 7 - 30 days before you have to buy it again, unless of course you pay real money for a permanent version of said gun. The movement feels stiff and clunky but the combat feels alright aside from that. Character creation is limited to only a few wipe sweeping options, and the game itself is lobby based where you jump into a map with a specific objective. This is a game feels like it's designed for passing the time here and there with a cashop designe that only the hardcore fan would utilize.

reviewText:
TL;DR:  It's a lackluster Gears-of-War-style game that has mediocre-to-bad mechanics and does virtually nothing to stand out from the crowd.

Full Review:

Man, where to start.

I will admit to not playing this game for very long.  If that means this is a bad review, take it for what it is.  But I only stopped playing it so quickly because the little of it I DID play left SUCH a bad taste in my mouth that I wasn't willing to force myself through any more of its mediocrity.

Basically Gears of War with an actual color palette, ZMR is a third-person cover-based shooter that utilizes the active reload" mechanic from GOW and has you fighting a variety of skins draped over generic enemies.  In general
date: the mechanics were below par; running and rolling was a little sticky
recommended: you have to scroll the mouse wheel to use the scope for the sniper rifle
hoursPlayed: the cover mechanic didn't work most of the time
voteText: and I never really had a good feel for how much health my character had.  Really
helpfulPercent: though
votesHelpful:
the mechanics are serviceable enough that the problems could be ignored if the rest of the game was good.

It wasn't.

My problems with this game began from the main screen.  The game requires a separate account with En Masse to play
votesTotal: but it wasn't immediately apparent
votesFunny: because it said that my steam account's auto-log-on had "failed".  It didn't fail
commentsCount: it just wasn't connected to an account.  Making an account was a little annoying due to the forced email verification
column16: but I've had more painful experiences on Steam with multiplayer games and MMOs before
column17: so it's harmless
column18: if a little backwards and bizarre\n\nI don't know exactly what they put in the code
column19: but it feels sloppy from a user perspective; just the launcher took a couple of tries to get working
column20: and the game took a while to launch
column21: and started by going into the minimized window that you usually see when you alt+tab out of the game.  It wasn't BROKEN
column22: but it's indicitive of the lack of polish in the rest of the game.  Oh
column23: and the game started windowed for some reason
column24: and I couldn't change that option until I got into a game.  More on that in a minute.\n\nWhen the game finally started
column25: I was immediately shunted into Character Creation.  It was a little jarring
column26: but I'd seen games do this before
column28: this was the best part of the game.  There weren't a LOT of options
column29: but there were more options than most games had at launch
column30: and they were evenly distributed between males and females.  They even had twelve distinct voice actors; six for each gender.  For some weird reason
column31: they give you multiple character slots in the game
column33: but I'd be surprised if your cosmetics and weapons carried over between characters
column34: so I was a little baffled as to why they gave you extra options
column35:
but it's certainly not a BAD thing.

Now things get a little MORE frustrating.

From the Character Creation screen
column36: you're FORCED to go through a tutorial.  There is no way to put it off and no way to ignore it.  It's one of THOSE tutorials
column37: too; the ones that assume you're too stupid to know that the WASD keys move you and the mouse looks.  It was pointless
column38: but mercifully short.  It's also the first time in the game you can change your settings... from the pause menu.  There's no way (as far as I could see) to set them up peacefully
column40: you set your options and finish the tutorial without trouble only to find the game has assigned you ANOTHER
column42: you're assigned to fight zombies (since the last tutorial didn't bother to include any enemies) and you're assigned an AI partner with one of the most overcompensating aimbots I've ever seen.  She mows down almsot every enemy
column44: and making me feel incompetant.  Yet even here
column45: I could feel the specter of the problem that dominated my playtime with the game.\n\nOnce you make your character and finish the two mandatory tutorials
column46: the game gives you a "mission" (like challenges in other games):  To finish a game of a specific type.  If I remember right
column47: it was called Assault.  You are then dumped onto a serverlist that's a chaotic
column48: unnavigable mess (as most server lists tend to be).  It probably had sorting tools
column49: but I didn't see them and didn't know how to use them even if I'd found them.  Luckily
column50: one of the tabs (the third one over for some reason) was a "mission" tab that let you select a mission
column51: hit "go!" and it would automatically put you into the appropriate match.\n\nThen I got into the match
column52: and my problems were immediate.  The issues with gameplay I had in the tutorial were magnified a hundredfold in actual combat.  My enemies this time were the "Robots" of Zombies Mosters Robots.  The game starts you off with an assault rifle
column56: most elephant-in-the-room issue with this game is the enemies.  No matter what enemy type I faced (the robots had several
column57: most of which were reskins of zombie enemies with guns)
column58: they went down like little ♥♥♥♥♥es.  The LMG is insanely overpowered
column60: meaning that you always have it.  It might be different on higher difficulties (we were playing on normal) but usually the first difficulty in a multiplayer game like this is somewhat challenging.  Here
column61: enemies were dull sacks of blood (yes
column62: blood.  from robots.) who popped when you looked at them funny.  Ammo was somewhat scarce
column63: but once I knew I had to manage it
column64: I had no problems with that
column65: either.  The only hard part came when all my teammates went down and left (I'm still not sure how or why) and I was the last person on the server.  At that point
column66: I was under attack from all sides
column67: and the cover system was virtually pointless
column68: as there weren't really any choke points I could funnel enemies down.  I went down a couple of times.\n\nMy real
column69: overarching issue with this is that the unlocks in the game are almost entirely new weapons (usually on a timed limit for some reason)
column70: but while new weapons would have given the damage bonus I needed to tackle harder waves
column71: they wouldn't have made soloing that mission any easier.  I was basically killing anything I looked at anyway; it was just the ludicrous amount of targets that brought me down
column72: more via attrition than anything else (and there wasn't a single health pickup in sight
column73: by the way.  Not that I know for a fact how health worked
column75: unlike walking with WASD and pressing mouse 1 to shoot
column76: that was deemed an unimportant thing to teach the player).  When a few other players dropped in at the end
column77: we mopped up the rest of the enemies
column78: and I felt less like my occasional low killcounts were because I was low-level or bad at the game and more that enemies just spawned closer to the other guy.\n\nBottom line:  When a multiplayer shooter based around unlocks fails to provide unlocks that are useful to the player
column79: is there even a game to play anymore?\n\nAlso
column80: for a shooter in this day and age to do so little to set itself apart is criminal.  Comparing it to
column83: that game at least provides some unique tools like the giant robots and vertical movement to make matches interesting.  This game wallows in mechanics that were overused when Gears of War 3 came out and does absolutely nothing to provide a unique gameplay experience.\n\nFinal Score:  5/10 by most game journalist standards.  It's boring

reviewText:
I loved that this game was made by some of the same guys that made gears. I loved that this game's mechanics are similar in regards to gears. But that's all I love.

The game is fundamentally flawed starting with your choice of guns. You don't necessarily unlock guns by leveling up, you unlock them by purchasing them with gold you get from games played. Now that doesn't necessarily sound bad, but in PvP you'll get spawn camped like it's going out of style. Also the bulk of the weapons that you can get are EXPLICITLY for players who pay.

If you're looking for a fun game to play then look away. This game is pay to win down to the core. Such a shame.

reviewText:
-I do not reccomend this game unless you plan to play online with large groups of friends-

GOODS:
This game is by far one of the funnest games to play online co-op on. Its great to get a big group of friends togehter and start waves of zombie survival. Or, Play a fair game of PVP and vs. each other.

BADS:
I personally hate this game, mostly because its is completly copying Gears of War. Everything is the same, All the animations, Active-Reloads, Maps, Environments, Characters and even enemies. You play this game for 5 minutes and tell me that some of the enemies don't look like Locusts from Gears. And finally, I think the thing I hate most about this game is the gamplay, Yes its fun online with big groups of friends. But alone its just SO BORING. There are only 8 waves per game and the enemies never seem to get harder. More enemies come, but they all have the same amount of health. So there is never any challenge to the game. This game may be free, But don't waste your time downloading it. Go buy a game thats worth your time. (GEARS OF WAR)

reviewText:
ZMR's storytelling in a nutshell: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JC3y0eDEN1A

P' good for a free game, but falls short in replay value because of lack of content. Compared to some other free shooters out there, ZMR has a pretty solid CoOp experience going for it provided you've got a buddy to tag along. Otherwise it devolves rather quickly into a grind, which is made more frusterating by most weapons being rentals (I'm looking at you, Blacklight).

Now when I say ZMR is short on content I mean that there are only a few maps, and the enemies range from full ♥♥♥♥♥♥ that can only walk a straight line and mech-hitler that will one shot you and your family if you look at him wrong. That aside, this game is Blacklight: Retribution's superior at least because its grind is nowhere near painful and it does not appear to suffer P2W at all.

Also reminds me of Bulletstorm because it has that reloading mechanic Gears had.

Speaking of mechanics, the game gives you 3 free respawns each game. After those have been used you must use your own permanent respawn tokens (which are won from completing missions). This makes wave spawn gametypes a little more difficult because every mistake in a match can affect you in the long run. It's really a clever way to make their stupid zombies a little more threatening.


Pros:
+Little to no pay-to-win
+Free
+Unique enemies
+Easy grind

Cons:
-Can get repetitive
-Rental equipment

Rating: 7/10 Played once then uninstalled."
"

reviewText: I used to love this game....until the last couple days I was playing.  I was willing to put up with the cheaters and the high pings from players outside NA.  I made a couple comments today about the increase in hacking that I have observed in the past little while and I was called numerous names over megaphone and whispered to by people who thought they were the games elite.  They said I was ruining the game by making comments like that.  I never hackusate people specifically but I have been playing video games, and this game, long enough to know what you can and cant do...or whats possible and what is just luck and what is simply botting or whatever.  This game is no longer worth it.  Its free to play, and even void of a lot of pay to winness I've seen in other games.  I have even been tempted to pay real money to buy outfits and other things in the cash shop.  They say they are doing what they can about the hacking....but there is no anti-cheat system or any way of reporting cheaters.  I will still play this game from time to time, but I will never spend money on it or really ever put much time into it.  Spare yourself some anger and frustration....play something else.

reviewText: As with APB Reloaded the guns seem to be by and large time based weapons, i.e. you can only use it for 7 - 30 days before you have to buy it again, unless of course you pay real money for a permanent version of said gun. The movement feels stiff and clunky but the combat feels alright aside from that. Character creation is limited to only a few wipe sweeping options, and the game itself is lobby based where you jump into a map with a specific objective. This is a game feels like it's designed for passing the time here and there with a cashop designe that only the hardcore fan would utilize.

reviewText:
My friends and I have been playing this game for a couple days now. Here's a skin-deep analysis of the game.

Pros:
Easy to understand
Fun*
Free-to-Play
Each mission feels different
Each enemy feels different
Cover-based mechanics*

Cons:
Finding a party of equivalent level people is hard solo
Cover-based mechanics*

*See mechanics

Graphics: Acceptable. While not visually stunning, they get the point across efficiently and passingly. 4/5.

Mechanics: Well, this is a fairly average shooter game. It doesn't add anything new or exciting to the formula of cover-based shooters if you've been through enough of them. Each character can hold two weapons, a sidearm (Pistol or Melee Weapon), and several modifiers (think of these as like MMO traits, +5-10% movement speed, etc.) You can take cover and blind-fire, which interacts interestingly with some of the enemies in PVE. There are certain enemies (Flamers, Chargers, etc.) which will try to drive you out of cover, while certain enemies (snipers, heavies, etc.) do better against you when you are out of cover. So, teamwork and prioritization is important. This makes playing without a set group risky: you may find that your group is mostly incompetent, playing under their skill level, or just right for you.

My only mechanical gripe so far is that there is no Assist" points in PVE
date: meaning that players who use high burst damage (Shotguns and snipers) will score higher
recommended: even if they only finish off an enemy. Should this be fixed
hoursPlayed: I'd be more than willing to say this could be a 5$/Month game."

reviewText:
I actually kinda like this game. It has great replay value and it brings gametypes from a lot of different shooters. Im not too hot on the whole renting gun systems and stuff, but the silver/gold etc bullets offer permanent items i beleive (gotta be lucky though). For a f2p game, i think it looks pretty good and plays pretty smoothly. The enemies are basically reskins, but that didnt bother me all that much. I just kinda wish it was easier to get better gear and stuff without paying real money for it, but hey thats f2p for ya. The rental system is a cash grab kind of idea, but they gotta make money somehow. I just hope they will tweak somethings in the future, but so far the PvE has me hooked.

Pros: Smooth, pretty, remniscent of other shooters like gears, bosses are kinda fun, awesome for something that is f2P, and its smooth i think. Oh and radar saves my life, and my teammates, so many times in PVE. PVP seems ok, ive only played a couple, but i think thats where pay-to-win kind of rears its ugly head, not in an insane way though. I was an intern and played a couple rounds and actually won them...so yeah. It is really easy to die though. Also health regen when not getting attacked is nice.

Cons: enemies can get repetitive as well as the game types (but what do you expect, it is what it is, most every game can get a little repetitive), the rental system is bleh, and, to me at least, some of the guns just kind of blend together. What i mean is one assault rifle will feel just like the other ( at  least for some). Also, i only really started enjoying myself and killing a bunch of stuff when i passed one of my missions to get this SMG-ZK (surpirse its a rental), idk something ZK, that gives me extra damage in certain PvE game types. I feel like once that limit is up, im gonna find myself not really doing much damage.

reviewText: ZMR is a Third Person Shooter built of the same engine that Gears of War Judgement uses. It's actually developed by the same Chinese company, YingPei. It borrows the same chest-high cover mechanics and over the top melee executions but adds a lot more variety of PvE modes that run from classic Horde-mode maps to maps that pit you against gigantic T-Rexes with rocket launchers on their backs. Great game to play

YES FINALLY, A COMPANY THAT LISTENED, they added a level 11-20 room for PVP, but that is only trival according to what I am about to say.

Thank You EN MASSE for adding free content such as the updates including maps. This makes it so I and others can play this game.

Ratings

CO-OP 8.5/10
great ideas, but sometimes enemies are immensely overpowered. Large level design including new content from updates, and adding new meshes and textures.

PVP 0/10
All but dead, the great imbalence of pay-to-win weapons, that are used against large zombies, and kill them in one hit were not toned down to be balenced. Some guns could fire through barriers, giving the ablility for 2 or more people to destroy everyone. (This was the Thunder Crossbow I think) Speed boosts allowed a person to dodge whole clips of some guns and doesn't affect accuracy. Thank GOD this has been all but abandoned by the player base.

reviewText:
I actually kinda like this game. It has great replay value and it brings gametypes from a lot of different shooters. Im not too hot on the whole renting gun systems and stuff, but the silver/gold etc bullets offer permanent items i beleive (gotta be lucky though). For a f2p game, i think it looks pretty good and plays pretty smoothly. The enemies are basically reskins, but that didnt bother me all that much. I just kinda wish it was easier to get better gear and stuff without paying real money for it, but hey thats f2p for ya. The rental system is a cash grab kind of idea, but they gotta make money somehow. I just hope they will tweak somethings in the future, but so far the PvE has me hooked.

Pros: Smooth, pretty, remniscent of other shooters like gears, bosses are kinda fun, awesome for something that is f2P, and its smooth i think. Oh and radar saves my life, and my teammates, so many times in PVE. PVP seems ok, ive only played a couple, but i think thats where pay-to-win kind of rears its ugly head, not in an insane way though. I was an intern and played a couple rounds and actually won them...so yeah. It is really easy to die though. Also health regen when not getting attacked is nice.

Cons: enemies can get repetitive as well as the game types (but what do you expect, it is what it is, most every game can get a little repetitive), the rental system is bleh, and, to me at least, some of the guns just kind of blend together. What i mean is one assault rifle will feel just like the other ( at  least for some). Also, i only really started enjoying myself and killing a bunch of stuff when i passed one of my missions to get this SMG-ZK (surpirse its a rental), idk something ZK, that gives me extra damage in certain PvE game types. I feel like once that limit is up, im gonna find myself not really doing much damage.

reviewText:
To all the people having problems starting the game: I say get a better f***ing computer.

This has to be the second best Free to Play game I have ever experienced, second only to Team Fortress 2. Sure it has a cash shop like most games of the same genre, but most of it is unnecessary as with a little bit of luck you can get some of the best weapons for free using in-game gold and rep tokens, as well as a reward system with bullets that you get from completing any PvE map to use in a shooting gallery to get plentiful and helpful rewards. It may be a bit repetitive at times, but En Masse has shown that they are still providing updates with new maps, missions, guns and costumes. On top of that, every 5 levels you gain, you will earn a free Thresher weapon, which will do 1.5x damage in ALL PvE modes.

Its not without faults however. There are many glitches that En Masse still has not fixed, but nothing that will take the enjoyment out of the game.

The player base however is another story... 90% of the population is Brazilians and Russians that don't speak a word of english, even though the servers are based in North America. They constantly slow down the game, be it them acting completely stupid or lagging the entire server.

I give it a solid 8/10, fun to play for small periods at a time, but not really worth putting all your effort (and money) into.
But hey, if you want to buy the packs and costumes, be my guest, they will certainly give you an advantage.
